filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions of three copies of The [First] Book of Urizen. Copies A, C, and F were beautifully and extensively color printed in the same printing session in 1794. This is the first time that Copies C and F have been reproduced, and the first reproduction of Copy A since 1929.
Copies A and C are in the Yale Center for British Art, Yale University, and Copy F is in the Houghton Library, Harvard University. These three copies join Copy G, from the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress, and together comprise half the extant copies of The [First] Book of Urizen. Two other copies of Urizen, Copy D, from the 1794 printing and Copy B from the 1795 printing, are forthcoming.
Blake etched in shallow relief the twenty-eight plates of The [First] Book of Urizen in 1794, although only Copies A and B contain them all. In the same year, he printed proof Copies H and I (only 3 and 2 plates respectively) and Copies A, C, D, E, F, and J. Copy B was printed the following year as part of a set of large-paper copies of the illuminated books and Copy G was printed in 1818. Plate 4 appears only in Copies A-C (an impression was pulled for Copy G but not included). The full-page designs are differently positioned in each copy; Copies A, B, E, and F also have variant orders of text plates.
The electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4x5" transparencies; text and images are fully searchable and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates. With the Archive's recently added comparison feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across the different copies of an illuminated book. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all the Urizen texts, including previously published Copy G.
With the publication of these three copies, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 48 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. They also join the Thomas Butts set of Blake's watercolors illustrating the Book of Job, and Blake's twelve water-color illustrations to John Milton's poems "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso," the first of several series of Milton illustrations that we will be adding in Preview mode. In the near future we expect to release more drawings and prints in Preview mode, which provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote, a much-anticipated electronic edition of Jerusalem Copy E, and further supplementary materials, including a biography and glossary.
The editors of the Archive recently photographed 125 works by Blake in the Department of Prints and Drawings, National Gallery of Art, Washington D. C., including biblical watercolors, pencil drawings, and proofs in various states of the Job engravings. We have obtained reproductions of the Blake collections of the Fogg Museum of Art, Victoria and Albert Museum, the Metropolitan Museum, National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, and the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery. Over the next few years, we will be adding to the Archive these extensive collections of books, prints, and drawings, many of which will be reproduced in color for the first time.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, by a major grant from the Preservation and Access Division of the National Endowment for the Humanities, by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is named as the printer on the title page, but he is also the "publisher."

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 16.8 x 11.7 and 14.2 x 9.1 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching, color printed with hand coloring
objinfo.inkcolor: green and orangish yellow ochreThe texts and accompanying interlinear motifs on Objects 1 and 15 (Bentley Plates 1 and 15) are printed in yellow ochre, but in green on all other plates bearing texts. The designs, both full-page designs and those on plates bearing texts, are color printed in a variety of colors, with yellow ochre one of the dominant hues.

provenance.name: Houghton Library, Harvard University
provenance.note: William Beckford, sold from his library, Sotheby's, 29 Nov. 1883, lot 764, bound with *The Book of Thel* Copy A and *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy A (£121 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); the three works bound together offered by Quartich for £150 in his Jan. 1884 "Rough List" 67, item 80, and in his Nov. 1885 "Rough List" 73, item 51; E. W. Hooper by 1891, who disbound the book; Hooper's daughter, Mrs. Ward Thoron, before 1921; given by Mrs. Thoron to Harvard University in 1962.

repository.department: Department of Printing and Graphic Arts

desc.objtitle: THE FIRST BOOK of URIZENThe Book of Urizen, The [First] Book of Urizen, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a rigidly symmetrical composition, a willow-like tree with at most a few leaves forms a cave-like arch over the top half of the plate. The words of the title appear between the branches. A fully gowned old man with closed eyes and long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits cross-legged on a large book in the center foreground. Centered behind him is a pair of stone tablets with arched tops, like tombstones. Indeterminate dark forms, perhaps another arching tree, appear above and on both sides of the tablets. Lying on the ground to the man's left and right are two sets of quadrangular stone tablets or books or, alternatively, the ends of a single long tablet, perhaps a coffin lid. The dark background, trees, and tablets taken together suggest a graveyard setting. Beneath Urizen's feet is an open book. The toes of his right foot emerge from his beard to mark his place in the book. Tree roots sprout to left and right in the foreground beneath the book and tablets. Holding a writing instrument in each hand and resting his arms on the tablets to his left and right, Urizen seems to be copying from the book onto the tablets. The instruments may be quills, graphite pencils, or etching needles. Publication information is centered beneath the book.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits facing forward, legs crossed, on a book. With both hands, a writing instrument in each, he copies from the book onto stone tablets to his right and left with his arms resting on the tablets. The toes of his right foot mark his place in the book. His eyes are closed or looking sharply downward.

A willow-like tree on the left forms a cave-like arch over the top half of the plate that tightly encloses the tombstone-like tablets behind Urizen. There may be a few leaves on the branches near their termination on the right. Above the tablets are indeterminate dark forms that may be another arching tree growing up from the right and a branch from the main tree arching from the left. The words of the title appear between the branches of the tree growing from the left side of the design. Publication information appears between roots that sprout to left and right at the bottom of the plate.
A large open book on the ground provides a platform for Urizen to sit cross-legged on as he copies its text, which is represented by indecipherable marks.
Urizen holds instruments in both hands that may be quill pens, graphite pencils, or etching needles.

A stone tablet, or two tablets one on top of the other, or stacks of books provides one of the two surfaces on which Urizen writes. There may be only one tablet with its two ends showing. Its position and material suggest a coffin lid of some sort.
A pair of upright tablets resembling tombstones and the tablets of the decalogue sit directly behind Urizen.
The setting altogether suggests a graveyard.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Extensions of the letters of "URIZEN" (line 4) suggest vines, including a loopy spiral introducing the first letter.

component.illusobjdesc: Extensions of the letters of "URIZEN" (line 4) suggest vines, including a loopy spiral introducing the first letter.

desc.objtitle: PRELUDIUM TO THE BOOK OF URIZEN, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young woman wearing a full gown floats horizontally above the text. The woman fully extends her left arm parallel to the line of her body to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown.

component.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young female wearing a full, flowing gown hovers horizontally. She fully extends her left arm parallel to the line of her body to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown. Her hair is long, perhaps arranged into some sort of coiffure. Her right foot is prominent.
A naked infant, whose arm is held by a female, floats horizontally in line with her arm. Both arms are extended horizontally. The infant appears to be bald in this copy.
Flames, or flame-like vegetation, surround the text on all sides.
Flames, or flame-like vegetation, surround the text on all sides.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Right of the "N" of "URIZEN" (line 5) there is a falling figure. A loopy vine-like extension on the "y" of "solitary" (line 9) divides the stanzas from one another. A large leaf extends from the "D" of "Dictate" (line 11) and a vegetative squiggle from the "y" of "your" (line 12).

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the "N" of "URIZEN" (line 5) is a falling figure, with its arms raised horizontally.

A loopy vine-like extension on the "y" of "solitary" (line 9) separates the stanzas from one another. A large leaf extends from the "D" of "Dictate" (line 11) and a vegetative squiggle from the "y" of "your" (line 12).

lg.l: PRELUDIUM
TO
THE
FIRST BOOK OF
URIZEN
Of the primeval Priests assum'd power
When Eternals spurnd back his religion:
And gave him a place in the north,
Obscure. shadowy. void. solitary.
Eternals I hear your call gladly,
Dictate swift winged words. & fear not
To unfold your dark visions of torment.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short bushy hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread. Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, his entire body.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short bushy hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread.
Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, the figure's entire body.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate—with at least one flowery stem just to the left, large leaves below the left column of text, and a stem of buds, flowers, or leaves below the right column—also sends out tendrils that separate the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, usually but not always continuous with the central plant, separate most of the stanzas. Other stanzas are separated by flying insects and birds, sometimes in combination with the vegetation (as between lines 43 and 44 and lines 47 and 48).

component.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate—with at least one flowery stem just to the left, large leaves below the left column of text, and a stem of buds, flowers, or leaves below the right column—also sends out tendrils that separate the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, usually but not always continuous with the central plant, separate most of the stanzas and fill spaces at the ends of lines and around chapter headings.
In the left column, a line of several flying birds divides lines 19 and 20; a large bird flies lower right between lines 47 and 48.
A flying insect, with other insects (or birds) beside it, separates lines 43 and 44.

lg.l: 1. Lo, a shadow of horror is risen
In Eternity! Unknown, unprolific?
Self-closd, all-repelling; what Demon
Hath form'd this abominable void
This soul-shudd'ring vacuum? Some
said
'It is Urizen", But unknown, abstracted
Brooding secret, the dark power hid.
2. Times on times he divided, & measur'd
Space by space in his ninefold darkness
Unseen, unknown; changes appeard
Like desolate mountains rifted furious
By the black winds of perturbation
3. For he strove in battles dire
In unseen conflictions with shapes
Bred from his forsaken wilderness.
Of beast. bird, fish, serpent & element
Combustion. blast, vapour and cloud.
4. Dark revolving in silent activity:
Unseen in tormenting passions;
An activity unknown and horrible;
A self-contemplating shadow,
In enormous labours occupied
5. But Eternals beheld his vast forests.
Age on ages he lay, clos'd, unknown,
Brooding shut in the deep; all avoid
The petrific abominable chaos
6. His cold horrors silent, dark Urizen
Prepar'd; his ten thousands of thunders
Rang'd in gloom'd array stretch out across
The dread world. & the rolling of wheels
As of swelling seas, sound in his clouds
In his hills of stor'd snows, in his mountains
Of hail & ice; voices of terror,
Are heard, like thunders of autumn,
When the cloud blazes over the harvests
-tion
1. Earth was not: nor globes of attrac-
The will of the Immortal expanded
Or contracted his all flexible senses,
Death was not, but eternal life sprung
2. The sound of a trumpet the heavens
Awoke & vast clouds of blood roll'd
Round the dim rocks of Urizen, so nam'd
That solitary one in Immensity
3. Shrill the trumpet: & myriads of Eter
-nity

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer squarely. Spiky beams of light radiate above his head. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks. The design may depict the moment when the Eternals "saw his pale visage / Emerge from the darkness; his hand / . . . unclasping / The Book of brass" (Erdman page 72; plate not in this copy).

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer directly. Spiky beams of light radiate above his head. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book. His left leg is bent at the knee and drawn up toward his chest.
Urizen holds the top corners of a large book, perhaps the Book of Brass (Erdman page 72; plate not in this copy), that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate sends out leaves and tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, sometimes extensions of the central plant, divide some of the stanzas. Miscellaneous birds, serpents, and human figures occupy spaces left between stanzas and at the ends of lines.

component.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate sends out leaves and tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other tendrils and vines, sometimes extensions of the central plant, divide some of the stanzas, most notably stanzas 3 and 4. A very long leaf takes up the space at the end of line 21.

Miscellaneous birds occupy the spaces between stanzas and at the ends of lines. In the left column, a tiny bird or insect appears between lines 2 and 3. A larger bird with a forked tail and wings spread appears at the ends of lines 5-7. A line of nine tiny birds divides lines 16 and 17. In the right column, two birds divide lines 40 and 41.

At the ends of lines 18-19 there are five hovering figures. Some may have their arms extended. The two on the right seem to be in the "flames of Eternal fury" (line 19). The touches of color printing make these figures particularly obscure, even misshapened, in this copy.
The two hovering figures on the right at the end of line 19 seem to be in the "flames of Eternal fury" (line 19).
Between lines 30 and 31 are two hovering figures. The one on the left is gowned(?) and holds its arms extended toward the other.
Between lines 30 and 31 are two hovering figures. The one on the right is running with its arms raised horizontally.
A serpent, facing right with mouth open, appears at the end of line 42.
The tail of the "y" on "fury" at the end of line 19 turns into an especially squiggly—not exactly loopy—and vigorous separation between the stanzas at lines 19-20.

lg.l: In living creations appear'd
In the flames of eternal fury.
3. Sund'ring. dark'ning, thund'ring!
Rent away with a terrible crash
Eternity roll'd wide apart
Wide asunder rolling
Mountainous all around
Departing; departing: departing;
Leaving ruinous fragments of life
Hanging frowning cliffs & all between
An ocean of voidness unfathomable.
4. The roaring fires ran o'er the heav'ns
In whirlwinds & cataracts of blood
And o'er the dark desarts of Urizen
Fires pour thro' the void on all sides
On Urizens self-begotten armies.
5. But no light from the fires, all was
darkness
In the flames of Eternal fury
6. In fierce anguish & quenchless
flames
-ging
To the desarts and rocks he ran ra-
To hide, but he could not; combining
He dug mountains & hills in vast strengthIn Copy F, the first letter of "He" in lines 25 and 26 was changed from a lower-case "h" to an upper-case "H."
He piled them in incessant labour,
In howlings & pangs & fierce madness
Long periods in burning fires labouring
Till hoary, and age-broke, and aged.
In despair and the shadows of death.
7. And a roof vast petrific around,
On all sides he fram'd: like a womb;
Where thousands of rivers in veins
Of blood pour down the mountains to cool
The eternal fires beating without
From Eternals; & like a black globe
View'd by sons of Eternity. standing
On the shore of the infinite ocean
Like a human heart strugling & beating
The vast world of Urizen appear'd.
8. And Los round the dark globe of
Urizen,
Kept watch for Eternals to confine,
The obscure separation alone;
For Eternity stood wide apart,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, floats or swims on his back in dark water cut horizontally by waves. Alternatively, he may be rising to the surface of the water from beneath. The design may depict Urizen's report that he "repell'd / The vast waves, & arose on the waters / A wide world of solid obstruction" (Erdman page 72; plate not in this copy). His arms are raised at 135 degrees and his knees are drawn up toward his chest.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen from above, a nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, floats or swims on his back in dark water. Alternatively, he may be rising to the surface of the water from beneath. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and his knees are drawn up toward his chest. His hair and beard stream out into the water.
Urizen floats in what appears to be dark water cut horizontally by waves.

objnote.p: As printed fragments indicate, two lines of text, between lines 10 and 11, have been deleted from the copperplate. Erdman notes that these lines are "almost legible in Copy B" (page 805).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three nude male figures with serpents coiled around their bodies fall downward through, and into, flames. The figure on the left faces away and clutches his head in his hands. The figure on the right also clutches his head in his hands, but he falls backward with his face up rather than down and with his body, the most contracted of the three figures, facing the viewer. The figure in the middle faces outward with his arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees (relative to his body). The serpent's left-facing head and upper body encircle the middle figure's head, and the serpent's tail similarly encircles his feet and then terminates in small coils. Two mysterious faces, perhaps of animals, appear in the flames on each side of the torso of the middle figure. These faces look leonine (right) and serpent-like (left) in other copies, but are hard to identify in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He faces away and clutches his head in his hands.

A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He falls backward with his face up and with his body somewhat contracted and facing the viewer. His left leg is bent at the knee and drawn up toward his torso.

A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He faces outward, toward the viewer, with his arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees (relative to his body) and left foot prominently displayed. His hands are raised, palms out to the right and left. The shape made by the serpent's head and upper body suggest a halo.
A serpent coils around the body of a nude male.

A serpent coils around the body of a nude male. With jaws open, the serpent's left-facing head and upper body encircle the figure's head, and the serpent's tail similarly encircles the feet and then terminates in small coils.
A serpent coils around the body of a nude male.

Two mysterious faces appear in the flames on each side of the torso of the middle figure. The face on the left may be a serpent. The face on the right may be a man with a short, pointed beard or perhaps a lion. These identifications are clearer in other copies.
The figures are surrounded by dark flames.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two columns are divided by a central vine. This vine extends into the space left by deleted lines of text between stanzas 10 and 11 (lines 10-11). A separate, worm-like vine or root extends downward into this same area from the "p" of "sleep" (line 9). A line of birds appears between lines 2 and 3 to divide stanzas 8 from 9.

component.illusobjdesc: A line of five birds appears between lines 2 and 3 in the left column to divide stanzas 8 from 9.

The two columns are divided by a central tendril or vine with branches, perhaps with leaves or blossoms, extending into a space left by deleted lines between stanzas 10 and 11. Several other vines appear in interlinear spaces, including a large worm-like vine or root descending into the space between stanzas 10 and 11 near the right margin of the plate.

lg.l: As the stars are apart from the earth
9. Los wept howling around the dark
Demon:
And cursing his lot for in anguish,
Urizen was rent from his side:
And a fathomless void for his feet;
And intense fires for his dwelling.
10. But Urizen laid in a stony sleep
Unorganiz'd. rent from Eternity
11. The Eternals said; What is this? Death
Urizen is a clod of clay.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror, perhaps depicting the moment when "Los howld in a dismal stupor" (line 1).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror.
Swirling flames surround a male figure, perhaps Los.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central flame-like vine (or vine-like flame) divides the two columns, and its tendrils divide stanzas and fill some of the spaces at the ends of lines. The tendrils between stanzas 12 and 13 (lines 3-4) and stanzas 13 and 14 (lines 8-9) are especially vigorous.

component.illusobjdesc: A central flame-like vine (or vine-like flame) divides the two columns, and its tendrils divide stanzas and fill some of the spaces at the ends of lines. The tendrils or flames between stanzas 12 and 13 (lines 3-4) and stanzas 13 and 14 (lines 8-9) are especially vigorous.

lg.l: 12: Los howld in a dismal stupor,
Groaning! gnashing! groaning!
Till the wrenching apart was healed
13: But the wrenching of Urizen
heal'd not
Cold featureless, flesh or clay
Rifted with direful changes
He lay in a dreamless night
14: Till Los rouz'd his his fireIn Copy F, the "s" at the end of "fires" did not print.
affrighted
At the formless unmeasurable
death.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His hair streams back (or up) toward his feet. A beard, barely discernible from above along the edge of his jaw in some copies, makes it likely that this is Urizen. In beardless copies, such as this one, the figure may be identified with Los. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands, which in turn are braced on what may be rock, earth, or clouds at the bottom of the design. His left leg is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His hair streams back (or up) toward his feet. A beard, barely discernible from above along the edge of his jaw in some copies, makes it likely that this is Urizen. In beardless copies, such as this one, the figure may be identified with Los. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands. His left leg is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.
A surface of stone, earth, or clouds seems to support the weight of the figure.
A filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds, or Blake's attempt to represent air, partly envelops the left leg of the figure. Other curving lines at the top of the image suggest clouds.
The figure may be swimming in a body of dark water.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of stone. His left leg is placed forward and bent at the knee and his right leg extended behind, as if positioned to support the weight of the massive rock above. His arms, accordingly, are raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbows, in a position to support weight from above. His head and hands are hidden by the rock; alternatively he may be headless.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of rock. His left leg is placed forward and bent at the knee and his right leg extended behind, as if positioned to support the weight of the massive rock above. His arms, accordingly, are raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbows, in a position to support weight from above. His head and hands are hidden by the rock; alternatively he may be headless.

A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of rock. There may be three separate rocks arranged like a trilithon, with the upper horizontal supported by the two verticals on either side.

A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of rock. There may be three separate rocks arranged like a trilithon, with the upper horizontal supported by the two verticals on either side.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its tendrils and leaves, some loopy, others serpentine or flame-like, are extended to fill the spaces between some of the stanzas and at the beginnings and ends of short lines. Several bits of the vegetation, such as the vine between stanzas 5 and 6, are independent of the central stem. Stanzas 3 and 4 (lines 27-28) are separated by a line of three flying birds.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its tendrils and leaves, some loopy (line 20), others serpentine or flame-like (after 6, 12, 18, and 34), are extended to fill the spaces between stanzas (1-2, 4-5, 5-6) and at the beginnings and ends of short lines (such as the space after line 1). Some bits of the vegetation with similar function are independent of the central stem (such as the vine between stanzas 5 and 6).
Stanzas 3 and 4 (lines 27-28) are separated by a line of three flying birds. Nearby, leaves on the vine right of stanza 4 may suggest a line of flying birds.

lg.l: 1. Ages on ages roll'd over him!
In stony sleep ages roll'd over him!
Like a dark waste stretching chang'able
By earthquakes riv'n, belching sullen
fires
On ages roll'd ages in ghastly
Sick torment; around him in whirlwinds
Of darkness the eternal Prophet howl'd
Beating still on his rivets of iron
Pouring sodor of iron; dividing
The horrible night into watches.
2 And Urizen (so his eternal name)
His prolific delight obscurd more & more
In dark secresy hiding in surgeing
Sulphureous fluid his phantasies
The Eternal Prophet heavd the dark
bellows.
And turn'd restless the tongs; and the
hammer
Incessant beat; forging chains new & new
Numb'ring with links, hours days & years
3 The eternal mind bounded began to roll
Eddies of wrath ceaseless round & round
And the sulphureous foam surgeing thick
Settled. a lake, bright. & shining clear:
White as the snow on the mountains cold
4. Forgetfulness, dumbness, necessity!
In chains of the mind locked up,
Like fetters of ice shrinking together
Disorganiz'd. rent from Eternity.
Los beat on his fetters of iron:
And heated his furnaces & pour'd
Iron sodor and sodor of brass
5. Restless turnd the immortal inchain'd
Heaving dolorous! anguish'd! unbearable
Till a roof shaggy wild inclos'd
In an orb, his fountain of thought.
6. In a horrible dreamful slumber;
Like the linked infernal chain;
A vast Spine writh'd in torment
Upon the winds; shooting pain'd
Ribs, like a bending cavern
And bones of solidness, froze,
Over all his nerves of joy.
And a first Age passed over,
And a state of dismal woe,

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a space suggesting a cave or womb, a human skeleton, viewed from the side, sits in a severely contracted position with curved spine, head bowed, legs drawn up to head, and (the only visible) hand clutching the head. In the context of the gestation and birth metaphors of the text, the skeleton's position may suggest a fetus.

component.illusobjdesc: A human skeleton, viewed from the side, sits in a severely contracted position with curved spine, head bowed, legs drawn up to head, and (the only visible) hand clutching the head. In the context of the gestation and birth metaphors of the text, the skeleton's position may suggest a fetus huddled in a womb.
In a space meant to suggest a cave or womb, a human skeleton, viewed from the side, sits in a severely contracted position.
Green coloring here and there in the design suggests some sort of vegetation. If the setting is a cave, the vegetation might be lichens.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its sometimes loopy, sometimes flame- like tendrils separate stanzas (2 from 3—lines 6-7; 4 from 5—lines 10-11) and help fill the spaces at ends of lines. The "y" of "every" (line 12) becomes a separate vine that fills space at the end of line 13 and grows into a leafy branch that divides stanza 5 from 6 (lines 14-15). A line of five or six flying birds divides stanza 1 from 2 (lines 3-4).

lg.l: 1: Los smitten with astonish-
Frightend at the hurtling bones
2: And at the surging sulphure-
-ous
Perturbed Immortal mad raging
3: In whirlwinds & pitch & nitre
Round the furious limbs of Los
4: And Los formed nets & gins
And threw the nets round about
5: He watch'd in shuddring fear
The dark changes & bound every
change
With rivets of iron & brass;
6. And these were the changes
of Urizen,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man, presumably Urizen, with a beard and long hair crouches, supporting himself with his left knee and both hands on the ground. He is positioned at the mouth of a cave or in a cleft in a rock whose weight seems to bear down on his head and shoulders. His eyes would appear to be closed.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man, presumably Urizen, with long, flowing beard and hair crouches, supporting himself with his left knee and both hands on the ground. His eyes would appear to be closed. His right knee and right foot are prominent.
Urizen appears to be crouching in the mouth of a cave or a cleft in a rock surface.
Green coloring around the figure suggests vegetation, possibly lichens.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude male figures, with tormented expressions and their legs drawn up toward their chests, sit in or in front of a wall of upward-swirling flames (left) and darkness (right). The emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure on the left looks upward while holding his arms at his sides and resting his hands on his knees. The figure on the right sits with head tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side. If the figure on the right is Los, the round object at bottom right is probably one end of the "great hammer" that "fell from his hand" when he "shrunk from his task" (Plate 13, lines 22-24) after putting Urizen in chains. The figure on the left is shackled and chained around the ankles in this copy and thus may be Urizen.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with tormented, pained expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits in or near a wall of upward-swirling flames. The emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure looks upward, mouth slightly open, while holding his arms at his sides and resting his hands on his knees. He is shackled and chained at the ankles. He may be Urizen after being enchained by Los.

A nude male, perhaps Los, with tormented or pained expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits before a dome and leaning column or tower. His head is tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side, where a hammer rests. His hair is flame-like.
The figure on the left is shackled and chained around the ankles. The chains are connected to large rings or links just above the lower margin of the plate.
The figure on the left sits within or in front of upward-swirling flames that extend toward the text and to the right above the other figure. Darkness dominates the right background.
If the nude figure on the right is Los, the object in the lower right corner is probably the end of his hammer resting on the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. lg.l: 7. From the caverns of his jointed Spine,
Down sunk with fright a red
Round globe hot burning deep
Deep down into the Abyss;
Panting: Conglobing, Trembling
Shooting out ten thousand branches
Around his solid bones.
And a second Age passed over,
And a state of dismal woe.
8. In harrowing fear rolling round;
His nervous brain shot branches
Round the branches of his heart
On high into two little orbs
And fixed in two little caves
Hiding carefully from the wind.
His Eyes beheld the deep.
And a third Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
9. The pangs of hope began.
In heavy pain striving. struggling.
Two Ears in close volutions.
From beneath his orbs of vision
Shot spiring out. and petrified
As they grew. And a fourth Age passed
And a state of dismal woe,
10. In ghastly torment sick;
Hanging upon the wind;

Her upper body is twisted clockwise so that she faces right; her legs are extended to the right, and her left leg is drawn up.
A nude figure seems to be holding apart two clouds or stones.

lg.l: Two Nostrils bent down to the deep
And a fifth Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
11. In ghastly torment sick;
Within his ribs bloated round.
A craving Hungry Cavern
Thence arose his channeld Throat.
And like a red flame a Tongue
Of thirst & of hunger appeard
And a sixth Age passed over.The first letter of "Age" was written in acid-resist as both a lower-case "a" and an upper-case "A." Both letters were etched, and both print in Copy F.
And a state of dismal woe.
12. Enraged & stifled with torment
He threw his right Arm to the north
His left Arm to the south
Shooting out in anguish deep,
And his Feet stampd the nether Abyss
In trembling & howling & dismay,
And a seventh Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
1. In terrors Los shrunk from his
task;
His great hammer fell from his hand.
His fires beheld, and sickening.
Hid their strong limbs in smoke.
For with noises ruinous loud;
With hurtlings & clashings & groans
The Immortal endur'd his chains,
Tho' bound in a deadly sleep.
2, All the myriads of Eternity:
All the wisdom & joy of life:
Roll like a sea around him.
Except what his little orbs
Of sight by degrees unfold.
3, And now his eternal life
Like a dream was obliterated
4, Shudd'ring. the Eternal Prophet smote
With a stroke, from his north to south
region
The bellows & hammer are silent now
A nerveless silence, his prophetic voice
Siez'd; a cold solitude & dark void
The Eternal Prophet & Urizen clos'd
5. Ages on ages rolld over them
Cut off from life & light frozen
Into horrible forms of deformity
Los suffer'd his fires to decay
Then he look'd back with anxious desire
But the space undivided by existence
Struck horror into his soul.
6. Los wept obscur'd with mourning;
His bosom earthquak'd with sighs,
He saw Urizen deadly black,
In his chains bound, & Pity began.
7 In anguish dividing & dividing
For pity divides the soul
In pangs eternity on eternity
Life in cataracts pourd down his
cliffs
The void shrunk the lymph into Nerves
Wand'ring wide on the bosom of night
And left a round globe of blood
Trembling upon the Void

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits in a contracted position with knees drawn up to his chest, arms down at his sides. His wrists and ankles are shackled and his eyes are closed. Spiky beams of light emanate from behind his head. The dark earth tones of the background suggest a cave or other stony area.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits in a contracted position with knees drawn up to his chest, arms down at his sides. His wrists and ankles are shackled and his eyes are closed. Spiky beams of light emanate from behind his head. He faces forward, his head tilted slightly upward.
Spiky beams of light emanate from behind Urizen's head.
Urizen's wrists and ankles are shackled.
The dark earth tones of the background suggest a cave or other stony area.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three male figures, who may be the Eternals, are suspended, as if in a cloud, over a dark area, its surface curved like part of a globe. They may be erecting a tent, or at least drawing a curtain, between their world and Urizen's (Plate 18, lines 2-11). Between the group of figures above and the globe below are streaks of cloud and light that suggest sunrise or sunset. From the right the figures are: (1) the head of a male with long, white, flowing hair and beard and down-cast eyes; (2) a male, naked from the waist up, reaching down toward the earth with his left arm and hand, his fingers emitting slight indications of some substance, possibly drapery; (3) the head of a man with long hair and beard and eyes apparently closed.

component.illusobjdesc: Between the group of figures above and the globe below are streaks of cloud and light that suggest sunrise or sunset.

The head of an elderly male with long, slightly curly hair and beard appears just left of the central figure. He looks downward. There are no clear indications of clothing on the one visible part of his body, his right shoulder.

A male, perhaps braced on his right arm, bends forward and reaches down toward the dark globe with his left arm; his fingers emit slight indications of some substance, possibly drapery. He is nude from the waist up, but his lower back appears to be covered with a gown or drapery of some sort. His hair may be in tight curls.

The head of an old man with long, flowing white beard and eyes closed appears right of the central figure. The end of his beard seems to touch the globe below. He wears a gown or drapery over his back.
Three figures hover over a dark, curved part of a globe, possibly the earth.

From the central figure's fingers stream slight indications of a substance that may be the fabric of the tent erected by the Eternals, its curtains, flesh, or Blakean streams of gore. In this copy, the representation of this substance is very minimal and looks more like drapery than something biological.

From the central figure's fingers stream slight indications of a substance that might be the fabric of the tent erected by the Eternals, its curtains, flesh, or Blakean streams of gore. The representation of this object or substance is minimal in this copy, making identification difficult.

lg.l: Thus the Eternal Prophet was divided
Before the death-image of Urizen
For in changeable clouds and darkness
In a winterly night beneath,
The Abyss of Los stretch'd immense:
And now seen. now obscur'd to the eyes
Of Eternals, the visions remote
Of the dark seperation appear'd.
As glasses discover Worlds
In the endless Abyss of space.
So the expanding eyes of Immortals
Beheld the dark visions of Los,
And the globe of life blood trembling

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male with curly hair, Los, stands in the midst of flames. His legs are spread, his genitals exposed, and his arms raised horizontally. In his left hand he holds a large hammer, which rests on what may be a broken pillar or anvil. He rests his right hand on a stone or broken pillar.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with curly hair, Los, stands in the midst of flames. His head is bent back and to the left. His legs are spread, his genitals exposed, and his arms raised horizontally. In his left hand he holds a large hammer. He rests his right hand on a stone or broken pillar.
Los is holding a large hammer in his left hand.

Los's hammer may be resting on a stone pillar or an anvil. Another such object appears below his left forearm. His right arm and hand also rest upon what appear to be blocks of stone. These may all be part of a ruined wall or building.
Los stands in the midst of flames.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its serpentine or flame- like extensions fill the spaces at the ends of two short lines. An independent vine forms an extension of the "W" at the beginning of stanza 10 (line 14) and wraps around the end of the line above.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its serpentine or flame- like extensions fill the spaces at the ends of two short lines to the left. An independent vine forms from an extension of the "W" (line 14) at the beginning of stanza 10 and wraps around the end of the line above.

lg.l: 8. The globe of life blood trembled
Branching out into roots;
Fib'rous, writhing upon the winds:
Fibres of blood, milk and tears:
In pangs. eternity on eternity,
At length in tears & cries imbodied
A female form trembling and pale
Waves before his deathy face
9. All Eternity shudderd at sight
Of the first female now separate
Pale as a cloud of snow
Waving before the face of Los
10, Wonder, awe, fear, astonishment
Petrify the eternal myriads,
At the first female form now separate

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure with long hair, perhaps Los creating Enitharmon (or Enitharmon herself), bends forward toward the viewer over a large red globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. He raises his arms at 135 degrees and holds his hands vertically to his head and perhaps over his ears. Nerves, or sinews, or cords of drapery, or perhaps blood in veins stream over the figure's lower back and along what may be his legs on either side of his back. His hair, perhaps fused with the lines on his back, cascades around the globe. The design may depict the "globe of life blood" that "trembled / Branching out into roots" to embody a "female form trembling and pale . . . the first female now separate" (Plate 16, lines 2-11).

component.illusobjdesc: A figure with long hair bends forward toward the viewer over a large red globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. He raises his arms at 135 degrees and holds his hands vertically to his head and perhaps over his ears. Nerves, or sinews, or cords of drapery, or perhaps blood in veins stream over the figure's lower back and along what may be his legs on either side of his back. His hair, perhaps fused with the lines on his back, cascades around the globe. He may be Los creating Enitharmon (Plate 16, lines 2-9) or Enitharmon herself.
A figure bends forward over a large red globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. This may be the "globe of life blood" (Plate 16, line 2).

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left a nude female with long hair stands or runs with her body arched and twisted sharply to the left, her right foot forward, and her only visible hand raised to her forehead. On the ground beside her to the right sits a second nude figure, probably male, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head. The two figures may be Los and Enitharmon: "the first female now separate / Pale as a cloud of snow / Waving before the face of Los" (Plate 16, lines 11-13). The white line to the right of the woman's legs and the dark lines to the left of her legs suggest the outlines of clouds or stones.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left a nude female with long hair, perhaps Enitharmon, stands or runs with her body arched and twisted sharply to the left, her right foot forward, and her only visible hand raised to her forehead. Her mouth appears to be slightly open.
On the ground to the right sits a nude figure with long hair, probably male, perhaps Los, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head.
The white line to the right of the woman's legs and the dark lines to the left of her legs suggest the outlines of clouds or stones.
Green coloring and leaf-like forms below the kneeling figure hint at vegetation.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils help fill the spaces at ends of short lines to the left of center. One tendril fills the space between stanzas (10-11, top left) and another helps fill the space around a chapter heading (chapter 6 in the left column). Detached leaves or stems are particularly prominent at the top of the right column. A few tendrils independent of the central vine, several generated as extensions of letters in the text, fill spaces in the right column. The serpentine extension of the "t" in "serpent" (line 30) and the loopy extension of the "s" at the end of "resistless" (line 48) are notable. Flanking the chapter 6 heading, two figures(?) hover horizontally, their arms extended.

A few tendrils independent of the central vine, several generated as extensions of letters in the text, fill spaces in the right column. The serpentine extension of the "t" in "serpent" (line 30) and the loopy extension of the "s" at the end of "resistless" (line 48) are notable.
Flanking the chapter 6 heading in the left column, two figures(?) hover horizontally. They face the text, their arms extended. A flag-like piece of drapery floats behind the figure on the left.
Flanking the chapter 6 heading in the left column are two hovering figures. They face the text, extending their arms, with bodies horizontal. The figure on the right may have its legs spread.

lg.l: They call'd her Pity, and fled
11. "Spread a Tent. with strong cur-
-tains around them
"Let cords & stakes bind in the Void
That Eternals may no more behold them"
12. They began to weave curtains of
darkness
They erected large pillars round the Void
With golden hooks fastend in the pillars
With infinite labour the Eternals
A woof wove. and called it Science
1. But Los saw the Female & pitied
He embrac'd her, she wept, she refus'd
In perverse and cruel delight
She fled from his arms; yet he followd
2. Eternity shudder'd when they saw,
Man begetting his likeness,
On his own divided image.
3. A time passed over, the Eternals
Began to erect the tent;
When Enitharmon sick,
Felt a Worm within her womb.
4. Yet helpless it lay like a Worm
In the trembling womb
To be moulded into existence
5. All day the worm lay on her bosom
All night within her womb
The worm lay till it grew to a ser-
-pent
With dolorous hissings & poisons
Round Enitharmons loins folding.
6, Coild within Enitharmons womb
The serpent grew casting its scales
With sharp pangs the hissings began
To change to a grating cry,
Many sorrows and dismal throes.
Many forms of fish, bird & beast
Brought forth an Infant form
Where was a worm before.
7. The Eternals their tent finished
Alarm'd with these gloomy visions
When Enitharmon groaning
Produc'd a man Child to the light.
8. A shriek ran thro' Eternity:
And a paralytic stroke;
At the birth of the Human shadow.
9. Delving earth in his resistless
way;
Howling, the Child with fierce flames
Issu'd from Enitharmon.
10. The Eternals, closed the tent
They beat down the stakes the cords

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the center of a burst of flames, a nude male infant or child, with head downward and limbs outspread, falls downward and to the right. The design may depict the birth of Orc: "Delving earth in his resistless / way; / Howling, the Child with fierce flames / Issu'd from Enitharmon" (Plate 18, lines 48-51).

component.illusobjdesc: At the center of a burst of flames, a nude male infant or child, probably Orc, with head downward and limbs outspread, falls downward and to the right.
A child falls at the center of a burst of flames.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with an unusual number of tendrils tangled in the central area separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, and in a few instances generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (from top left, stanzas 10-11, 1-2, 2-3, 5-6, 7-8, 9-10), around all three of the chapter headings (at the top center and in each column), and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "e" of "the" in line 30 and the "U" of "Urizen" in line 35. In the margin at lower right, in lieu of vines, flame-like shapes are extended upward from the large design below into the spaces at the ends of lines that begin chapter 8.

Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, and often generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (from top left, stanzas 10-11, 1-2, 2-3, 5-6, 7-8, 9-10), around all three of the chapter headings (at the top center and in each column), and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "e" of "the" in line 30 and the "U" of "Urizen" in line 35. The vine right of line 6 includes a loop.

lg.l: Stretch'd for a work of eternity;
No more Los beheld Eternity,
11. In his hands he siez'd the infant
He bathed him in springs of sorrow
He gave him to Enitharmon.
1. They named the child Orc, he grew
Fed with milk of Enitharmon
2, Los awoke her; O sorrow & pain!
A tight'ning girdle grew,
Around his bosom. In sobbings
He burst the girdle in twain,
But still another girdle
Opressd his bosom, In sobbings
Again he burst it. Again
Another girdle succeeds
The girdle was form'd by day;
By night was burst in twain.
3. These falling down on the rock
Into an iron Chain
In each other link by link lock'd
4. They took Orc to the top of a
mountain.
O how Enitharmon wept!
They chain'd his young limbs to the
rock
With the Chain of Jealousy
Beneath Urizens deathful shadow
5, The dead heard the voice of theIn Copy F, the ascender of the "d" in "heard" did not print.
child
And began to awake from sleep
All things, heard the voice of the child
And began to awake to life.
6. And Urizen craving with hunger
Stung with the odours of Nature
Explor'd his dens around
7. He form'd a line & a plummet
To divide the Abyss beneath.
He form'd a dividing rule:
8. He formed scales to weigh:
He formed massy weights;
He formed a brazen quadrant:
He formed golden compasses
And began to explore the Abyss
And he planted a garden of fruits
9, But Los encircled Enitharmon
With fires of Prophecy
From the sight of Urizen & Orc.
10. And she bore an enormous race
1. Urizen explor'd his dens
Mountain, moor, & wilderness,
With a globe of fire lighting his
journey
A fearful journey. annoy'd
By cruel enormities; forms

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tightly arranged group of three figures stands against a rocky cliff, perhaps covered by indeterminate vegetation. The figures, from left to right, are (1) a nude woman with long hair, her right arm at her side and holding some drapery in her right hand while looking down toward, (2) a nude child with short curly hair, probably male, seen from behind, who embraces the female with both arms; and (3) a bearded nude male, likewise looking down toward the child. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 19, line 28), hangs down the length of his body; its lower end terminates at his feet. The chain's upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest. He holds a large hammer with his right hand; his left arm is not clearly indicated, but may be raised horizontally. The hammer rests upon a pedestal or anvil. The trio likely represents Enitharmon and Los with the child Orc. A sun appears at the horizon on the left, sending out spiky beams of light.

component.illusobjdesc: Enitharmon, a nude woman with long hair, stands in contrapposto, right foot forward, while looking down toward Orc. Her head seems to touch the head of Los on the right. Her right arm is at her side and she holds some drapery, perhaps a cloak, in her right hand.
Orc, a nude and probably male child with short, curly hair seen from behind standing in contrapposto, embraces his mother Enitharmon with both arms raised. His head is turned upward.

Los, a bearded nude male standing in contrapposto, looks down toward Orc. His head appears to touch the head of Enitharmon, who stands close beside him. His hair is long and spiky. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 19, line 28) hangs down the length of his body. Its upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest. He holds a large hammer with his right hand. His left arm is not clearly indicated, but may be raised horizontally.
A sun appears on the horizon upper left. It sends out spiky beams of light.
A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 19, line 28) hangs down the length of Los's body. Its upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest.
Los holds a large hammer vertically. It rests on a pedestal or anvil.
Los's hammer rests on a pedestal or anvil.
Three figures stand against a cliff, perhaps covered with indeterminate vegetation indicated by green coloring.
Three figures stand against a cliff, perhaps covered with indeterminate vegetation on the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a dark, mountainous landscape opening onto an area of blue sky, a fully gowned male with long, flowing beard, probably Urizen, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm extends forward with the palm of the hand vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light. The head and front legs of a lion appear lower right. The illustration seems to depict the episode in which "Urizen explor'd his dens / Mountain, moor, & wilderness / With a globe of fire lighting his / journey" (Plate 19, lines 52-55).

component.illusobjdesc: Urizen, as a fully gowned male with long, flowing beard, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm is extended with his palm vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe. His eyes appear to be looking down.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of blue sky.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of blue sky.
The head and front leg(s) of a lion with long mane appear in profile.
With his right hand by his side Urizen holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like or, in one instance between stanzas 4 and 5, its loopy tendrils and leaves (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, often generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between all the stanzas on this plate and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are particularly extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "n" of "Fuzon" in line 20. The extensions of the central vine that sprout left and right below the text and around Urizen's head have shapes that may suggest serpents with (on the right) open mouths. Three or four flying birds help fill the space between stanzas 1 and 2.

Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "n" of "Fuzon" in line 20. lg.l: Of life on his forsaken mountains
2, And his world teemd vast enormities
Frightning: faithless; fawning
Portions of life; similitudes
Of a foot, or a hand, or a head
Or a heart, or an eye, they swam mis
-chevous
Dread terrors! delighting in blood
3, Most Urizen sicken'd to see
His eternal creations appear
Sons & daughters of sorrow on mountains
Weeping! wailing! first Thiriel appear'd
Astonish'd at his own existence
Like a man from a cloud born, & Utha
From the waters emerging, laments!
Grodna rent the deep earth howling
Amaz'd! his heavens immense cracks
Like the ground parch'd with heat; then
Fuzon
Flam'd out! first begotten, last born.
All his eternal sons in like manner
His daughters from green herbs & cattle
From monsters, & worms of the pit,
4. He in darkness clos'd, view'd all his
race
And his soul sicken'd! he curs'd
Both sons & daughters: for he saw
That no flesh nor spirit could keep
His iron laws one moment.
5. For he saw that life liv'd upon
death

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four human figures, probably representing the first four sons of Urizen, inhabit a compartmented landscape of sea, land, sky, and heavens. These sons of Urizen correspond to the classical elements of fire, air, earth, and water: "first Thiriel appear'd . . . Like a man from a cloud born, & Utha / From the waters emerging . . . Grodna rent the deep earth howling . . . then Fuzon / Flam'd out" (Plate 21, lines 13-21). Clockwise from the top: (1) Fire/Fuzon: A figure in flames, probably male, hovers horizontally, facing out toward the viewer with arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees. His position suggests the sun. (2) Air/Thiriel: Just below Fire, with nude body in an upward curve that reinforces the suggestion of a sun above, hovers a second figure, apparently male, with his hands raised to his chest and palms turned out. The red object below (and extending from?) him may be a bit of drapery with a loop in it or an extended vein, sinew, or umbilical cord. Between these upper two figures and the lower two is a curving, horizontal line of cloud. (3) Earth/Grodna: At lower right crouches a nude male with short, curly hair, head up, mouth open, and hands on the ground. He seems to be emerging from the earth, represented by a wave- washed island or peninsula of land. The form left and above his right elbow may be the coils of a serpent. (4) Water/Utha: At lower left, the upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. Above his head may be some vegetation-covered land.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure in flames, probably male, hovers horizontally, facing out toward the viewer with arms and hands upraised between the horizontal and 135 degrees, palms out. His hair is flame-like and his mouth is slightly open. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Fuzon, and the classical element fire. His position in the composition suggests the sun.
Flames envelop a hovering male figure, Fuzon/fire. Their shape helps to suggest the sun.

Just below the figure of Fuzon/fire, with nude body in an upward curve that reinforces the suggestion of a sun above, hovers a figure apparently male, with short, curly hair, mouth open, and hands raised, palms out. The red object below (and extending from?) him may be a bit of drapery with a loop in it, but it could even be an extended vein, sinew, or umbilical cord. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Thiriel, and the classical element air.
A line of cloud divides the top two figures from the bottom two.
An area of sky cut by a horizontal cloud is the transitional zone between fire and air (above) and water and earth (below).

A nude male with short and curly hair, head up, mouth open, and hands on the ground crouches, positioned as if emerging from the earth. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Grodna, and the classical element earth.
The object left and above the right elbow of the crouching figure, lower right, may be the coils of a serpent.
Grodna emerges from the surface of a wave-washed island or peninsula of land.
The green coloring of the earth below the figure lower right, to the right of his head and left shoulder, and above the head of the figure lower left suggests some sort of vegetation, possibly grass.
The head of Utha emerges from an area of dark water, which washes up in waves on an area of land.
The upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. He seems to be one of the first sons of Urizen, Utha, and the classical element water.

objnote.p: Just above the beginning of the text and centered on the plate are a few printed marks that may have been intended as a heading. If so, Blake converted these letter forms on the copperplate into mere squiggles. These marks appear in a position where Blake wrote headings on 9 other plates in .

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude and apparently female figures seem to be held in or emerging from the coils of giant worms or serpents; or, alternatively, the women may be the heads and upper bodies of the worms. The woman on the left has her right arm at her side and head tilted back and to the left. The serpent's coil wraps around her midriff, beneath which her body disappears. The woman to the right also faces to the left, her hands clutching her head. The head of a third woman appears just to the left of the head of the woman upper right. The scene is set in the midst of mostly indeterminate vegetation. Leafy structures edge the bottom and right margin of the design. A fourth figure, scaly, with bat wings, faces down, her head partly obscuring the upper body of the woman clutching her head. Her long hair falls over her face. She is hunched over in a quasi-crawling position, a serpent coiled around her midsection. The women may be Urizen's daughters, who are born "from green herbs & cattle / From monsters, & worms of the pit" (Plate 21, lines 23-24).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude woman seen from the bosom up, has her right arm at her side and head tilted back and to the left. The coil of a worm or serpent wraps around her midriff, beneath which her body disappears. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.
A nude woman, seen from the hips up, looks up and off to the left, her hands clutching her head. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.
Just the face of a third figure, possibly female, appears to the left of the head of the woman upper right.

Flanked by the other figures, a fourth woman, scaly, with bat wings, faces down, her head partly obscuring the upper body of the female clutching her head. Her long hair cascades downward, covering her face. She is hunched over in a quasi-crawling position, a serpent coiled around her midsection. She is probably one of Urizen's daughters.
The scene is set in the midst of mostly indeterminate vegetation. Leafy structures edge the bottom and right margin of the design.
Giant worms or serpents, perhaps bat-winged, coil around human figures. The tail of one such creature appears to the right of the woman clutching her head, upper right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine (even snake-like below line 48), flame- like, or loopy leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, a few of these generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (6-7, 7-8, 8-9, 1-2, 2-3, 3-4), at the foot of the left column, and around short lines. A bird flies right of the final line of stanza 3 (right column). Between stanzas 5 and 6 in the left column is a row of at least four figures, and other figures appear in the left column between stanzas 7 and 8 and between 8 and 9; in the right column, there are two figures between stanzas 1 and 2. An indistinct shape—perhaps a caterpillar or chrysalis—appears at the top of the central vine, in the center just above the text, but is partly obscured by color printing in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine (especially between stanzas 3 and 4 in the right column), flame-like, or loopy (after lines 2 and 9) leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, a few of these generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (6-7, 7-8, 8-9, 1-2, 2-3, 3-4), at the chapter break at the foot of the left column, and around short lines.
A bird flies right of the final line of stanza 3, right column.
Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 4 and 5), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of three or four human figures. The gowned one furthest to the right is hovering horizontally, arms extended.

Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 4 and 5), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of three or four human figures. The figure second from the right runs to the left with arm raised and leg extended backward.

Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 4 and 5), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of four human figures. Fourth from the right, a figure falls(?) upside down with arms raised horizontally and legs spread.
Between stanzas 7 and 8 (lines 21 and 22) a figure hovers with arms raised horizontally. Bits of drapery or a gown stream from the figure toward the left.
Between stanzas 1 and 2 (lines 35 and 36) two figures facing one another hover with their bodies horizontal and their arms extended toward one another. The legs on the right figure are spread.
Between stanzas 8 and 9 (lines 24 and 25) a gowned(?) figure hovers, facing down; its arms are extended.

An indistinct shape—perhaps a caterpillar or chrysalis—appears at the top of the central vine, in the center just above the text. In this copy, the shape is partly obscured by color printing from the main design above.

lg.l: The Ox in the slaughter house moans
The Dog at the wintry door
And he wept, & he called it Pity
And his tears flowed down on the winds
6. Cold he wander'd on high, over
their cities
In weeping & pain & woe!
And where-ever he wanderd in sorrows
Upon the aged heavens
A cold shadow follow'd behind him
Like a spiders web. moist. cold, & dim
Drawing out from his sorrowing soul
The dungeon-like heaven dividing.
Where ever the footsteps of Urizen
Walk'd over the cities in sorrow.
7. Till a Web dark & cold, throughout all
The tormented element stretch'd
From the sorrows of Urizens soul
And the Web is a Female in embrio
None could break the Web, no wings
of fire.
8. So twisted the cords, & so knotted
The meshes; twisted like to the
human brain
-gion
9 And all calld it, The Net. of Reli-
1. Then the Inhabitants of those Cities:
Felt their Nerves change into Marrow.
And hardening Bones began
In swift diseases and torments,
In throbbings & shootings & grindings
Thro' all the coasts: till weaken'd
The Senses inward rush'd shrinking,
Beneath the dark net of infection.
2. Till the shrunken eyes clouded over
Discernd not the woven hipocrisy
But the streaky slime in their heavens
Brought together by narrowing perceptions
Appeard transparent air: for their eyes
Grew small like the eyes of a man
And in reptile forms shrinking together
Of seven feet stature they remaind
3, Six days they shrunk up from existence
And on the seventh day they rested
And they bless'd the seventh day, in sick
hope:
And forgot their eternal life
4. And their thirty cities divided
In form of a. human heart
No more could they rise at will
In the infinite void, but bound down
To earth by their narrowing perceptions

illustration.illusobjdesc: Before a door or wall raked diagonally upper left by a shadow, a child in a full gown stands with his hands raised as if in prayer. His mouth is open slightly and eyes turned upward. Behind him, a dog, perhaps "The Dog at the wintry door" (Plate 23, line 2), stretched out in front of the door or wall holds its head raised vertically and mouth open as if howling.

Behind a child, a dog—perhaps "The Dog at the wintry door" (Plate 23, line 2)—stretched out in front of the lower edge of the door or wall holds its head raised vertically, mouth open as if howling.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object. The rounded shape upper left may be a stone or cloud.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or perhaps strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, palms vertical and fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object.
The rounded object left of the figure's left arm may be a cloud or large stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old man with full gown and long, flowing white beard and hair, presumably Urizen, sits or squats with eyes looking downward, arms raised horizontally, and hands hanging down. His arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right. There are slight suggestions of beams of light around his head. He is flanked by massive rope nets, one of which entangles his right shoulder. His left foot peeps out from his gown between the nets at the bottom of the design. The design probably depicts the "Web dark & cold" that "stretch'd / From the sorrows of Urizens soul / . . . / And all calld it, The Net. of Religion" (Plate 23, lines 16-26).

component.illusobjdesc: An old man with full gown and long, flowing white beard and hair, presumably Urizen, sits with eyes down, arms raised horizontally, and hands hanging down. His arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right. There is the slight suggestion of beams of light around his head. He is flanked by massive rope nets, one of which entangles his right shoulder. His left foot peeps out (improbably, considering the way his legs seem to be placed) from his gown between the nets at the bottom of the design. His knees are prominent.
Urizen is flanked by massive rope nets, probably the "Net. of Religion" (Plate 23, line 26), one of which entangles his right shoulder.
Urizen's arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An unusually simple central vine divides the left from the right column of text. The vine has few extensions: a large single leaf or spiky flower at the end of line 9 and a sprig between stanzas 6 and 7. A few other bits of vegetation, independent of the central vine, are notable: a serpentine or flame-like tendril in the top right corner and an elaborate extension of the initial "T" in "The End" (after line 25). At the foot of the right column is an outstretched corpse.

component.illusobjdesc: A human body, probably a corpse, lies supine at the end of the right column of text.

lg.l: They lived a period of years
Then left a noisom body
To the jaws of devouring darkness
5. And their children wept, & built
Tombs in the desolate places.
And form'd laws of prudence, and
call'd them
The eternal laws of God
6, And the thirty cities remaind
Surrounded by salt floods, now call'd
Africa; its name was then Egypt.
7. The remaining sons of Urizen
Beheld their brethren shrink together
Beneath the Net of Urizen:
Perswasion was in vain;
For the ears of the inhabitants,
Were wither'd, & deafen'd, & cold;
And their eyes could not discern,
Their brethren of other cities,
8. So Fuzon call'd all together
The remaining children of Urizen:
And they left the pendulous earth:
They called it Egypt. & left it.
9, And the salt ocean rolled englob'd
The End of the
first book of Urizen.
